titleInfo.title: Contending with Language Difference in the Writing Center
titleInfo.subTitle: An Investigation of Attitudes and Expectations Toward Second Language Writers

mods:mods.abstract: Laura Greenfield and Karen Rowen argue that in order to realize the change potential within tutor education, writing center directors must look critically at how we have been designing and executing our tutor education courses. This dissertation addresses the call to examine the additional factors on which tutor education can be structured or restructured and what ideologies about language, and specifically second-language use, inhibit writing center administrators ability to decouple tutor-training from the unidirectional monolinguistic ideals that have historically been at the center of writing instruction. As one site of both language instruction and writing support, writing centers are an optimal space to analyze the assumptions that administrators and tutors bring to working with multilingual students. The writing center tutor education course is often where tutors learn the tacit theories that tell them what is "right" or "normal" in the writing center. I followed Johanek's (2000) lead in adopting an epistemologically mixed approach to this study. By "epistemologically mixed," I mean it accounts for multiple ways of knowing. This study uses CDA as its methodological grounding because it takes into account the social act of knowing and enables a researcher to analyze linguistic and semiotic details in light of larger social and political or, in the case of my study, institutional contexts. Huckin et al. (2012) describes critical discourse analysis "as an interdisciplinary approach to textual study that aims to explicate abuses of power promoted by those texts, by analyzing linguistic/semiotic details in light of the larger social and political contexts in which those texts circulate" (p. 107). Because I examined the attitudes and expectations about second language writing through the use of interviews, it was essential that this research was grounded in a methodology that accounts for both the context and theory. This study has three key findings: (a) writing Center Administrators who had experience in either linguistics or TESOL took a more second language studies approach while those that had little or no formal preparation in TESOL or linguistics took a more translingual approach to working on language diversity; (b) when writing center administrators lacked expertise in expertise in the very areas that their L2/ESL/residential multilingual students need they have a tendency to hook onto the agendas that they can understand; and (c) one of the central reasons that writing center administrators are hesitant to train tutors to offer linguistic feedback is because they are afraid of being labeled as racist, or not anti-racist enough.
